text_resource.text:
#-1 WIKIPEDIA o ‘The Free Encyclopedia 
}iarald Cramér 
Harald Cramér (Swedish: [kra'me:r]; 25 September 
1893 — 5 October 1985) was a Swedish mathematician, 
actuary, and statistician, specializing in mathematical 
statistics and probabilistic number theory. John 
Kingman described him as "one of the giants of 
statistical theory".l!] 
Biography 
Early life 
Harald Cramér was born in Stockholm, Sweden on 25 
September 1893. Cramér remained close to Stockholm 
for most of his life. He entered the Stockholm 
University as an undergraduate in 1912, where he 
studied mathematics and chemistry. During this period, 
he was a research assistant under the famous chemist, 
Hans von Euler-Chelpin, with whom he published his 
first five articles from 1913 to 1914.12] Following his lab 
experience, he began to focus solely on mathematics. He 
eventually began his work on his doctoral studies in 
mathematics which were supervised by Marcel Riesz at 
the Stockholm University. Also influenced by G. H. 
Hardy, Cramér's research led to a PhD in 1917 for his 
thesis "On a class of Dirichlet series". 
Academic professional career 
Following his PhD, he served as an Assistant Professor 
of Mathematics at Stockholm University from 1917 to 
1929. Early on, Cramér was highly involved in analytic 
number theory. He also made some important 
statistical contributions to the distribution of primes 
and twin primes. His most famous paper on this subject 
is entitled "On the order of magnitude of the difference 
between consecutive prime numbers",3] which 
provided a rigorous account of the constructive role in

Cramérs inequality 
Marta Hansson

statistical theory".l!]

September 1893. Cramér remained close to Stockholm 
for most of his life. He entered the Stockholm 
University as an undergraduate in 1912, where he 
studied mathematics and chemistry. During this period, 
he was a research assistant under the famous chemist, 
Hans von Euler-Chelpin, with whom he published his 
first five articles from 1913 to 1914.12] Following his lab

the Stockholm University. Also influenced by G. H. 
Hardy, Cramér's research led to a PhD in 1917 for his

and twin primes. His most famous paper on this subject 
is entitled "On the order of magnitude of the difference 
between consecutive prime numbers",3] which 
provided a rigorous account of the constructive role in

text_resource.text:
which probability applied to number theory!4! and | Children 3 
included an estimate for prime gaps that became known | aAwards Guy Medal (Gold, 1972) 
as Cramér's conjecture. A Scientific career 
In the late 1920s, Cramér became interested in the field | Fields Statistics, Probability theory, 
of probability, which at the time was not an accepted Number theory 
branch of mathematics. Cramér knew that a radical | nstitutions  Stockholm University 
change was needed in this field, and in a paper in 1926 1 . . Doctoral Marcel Riesz 
said, "The probability concept should be introduced by a advisor 
purely mathematical definition, from which its s 
fundamental properties and the classical theorems are DtO(:or:I Kai Lai Chung students deduced by purely mathematical operations."!5] Cramér Ulf Grenander 
took an interest in the rigorous mathematical Leo Térnqvist 
formulation of probability in the work of French and Herman Wold 
Russian mathematicians such as Kolmogorov, Lévy, 
Bernstein, and Khinchin in the early 1930s. Cramér also 
made significant development to the revolution in 
probability theory.[5] Cramér later wrote his careful study of the field in his Cambridge publication 
Random variables and probability distributions which appeared in 1937 (with a 2nd edition in 1962 
and a 3rd edition in 1970).16] Shortly after World War II, Cramér went on to publish the influential 
Mathematical Methods of Statistics in 1946.I7J8] This text was one that "showed the way in which 
statistical practice depended on a body of rigorous mathematical analysis as well as Fisherian 
intuition."™ His 1955 book Elements of Probability Theory and Some of its Applications introduces 
probability theory at a more elementary level than Mathematical Methods of Statistics.l9) 
Bertil Matérn 
In 1929, Cramér was appointed to a newly created chair in Stockholm University, becoming the first 
Swedish professor of Actuarial Mathematics and Mathematical Statistics. Cramér retained this 
position up until 1958.12°] During his tenure at Stockholm University, Cramér was a PhD advisor for 
10 students, most notably Herman Wold and Kai Lai Chung. In 1950 he was elected as a Fellow of the 
American Statistical Association."!] Starting in 1950, Cramér took on the additional responsibility of 
becoming the President of Stockholm University. In 1958, he was also appointed to be Chancellor of 
the entire Swedish university system. Cramér retired from the Swedish university system in 1961. 
Actuarial career 
A large portion of Cramér's work concerned the field of actuarial science and insurance mathematics. 
During the period from 1920 to 1929, he was an actuary for the life insurance company Svenska 
livforsakringsbolaget. His actuarial work during this time led him to study probability and statistics 
which became the main area of his research."2! In 1927 he published an elementary text in Swedish 
Probability theory and some of its applications. Following his work for Svenska livforsakringsbolaget, 
he went on to work for Aterforsikringsaktiebolaget Sverige, a reinsurance company, up until 1948. He 
was also known for his pioneering efforts in insurance risk theory. After this period, he remained as a 
consultant actuary to Sverige from 1949 to 1961. Later in his life, he was elected to be the Honorary 
President of the Swedish Actuarial Society.[4]

text_resource.text:
Later years 
Cramér remained an active contributor to his professional 
career for an additional 20 years. Following his retirement in 
1961, he became extremely active in research, which had been 
slowed due to his Chancellorship. During the years from 1961 
to 1983, Cramér traveled throughout the United States and 
Europe to continue his research, making significant stops at 
Berkeley, Princeton, and at the Research Triangle Institute of 
North Carolina. 
Cramér received an Honorary Doctorate from Heriot-Watt 
University in 1972.113] 
His academic career spanned over seven decades, from 1913 
to 1982.[14] 
Harald Cramér married Marta Hansson in 1918, and they 
remained together up until her death in 1973. He had often 
referred to her as his "Beloved Marta". Together they had one 
daughter, Marie-Louise, and two sons, Tomas and Kim. Marta Cramér 
Notes

2. Heyde, Seneta 2001, p. 439.

numbers" (http://matwbn.icm.edu.pl/ksiazki/aa/aa2/aa212.pdf) (PDF), Acta Arithmetica, 2: 23-46, 
doi:10.4064/aa-2-1-23-46 (https://doi.org/10.4064%2Faa-2-1-23-46) 
4. Kendall 1986, p. 211. 
5. Blom 1987, p. 1340. 
6. Cramér, Harald (2004). Random variables and probability distributions (https://books.google.com/ 
books?id=QW3kkBzd0OQC). Cambridge Tracts in Mathematics and Mathematical Physics, No. 
36. Cambridge University Press. ISBN 0-521-604869; pbk reprint of 1970 3rd edition 
10. 
. Scheffé, H. (1947). "Review of Mathematical methods of statistics by H. Cramér" (https://projecteu 
clid.org/journals/bulletin-of-the-american-mathematical-society-new-series/volume-53/issue-7/Revi 
ew-H-Cramér-Mathematical-methods-of-statistics/bams/1183510865.full). Bulletin of the American 
Mathematical Society. 53 (7): 733—735. doi:10.1090/S0002-9904-1947-08838-8 (https://doi.org/1 
0.1090%2FS0002-9904-1947-08838-8). 
. Cramér, H. (1999). Mathematical Methods of Statistics (https://books.google.com/books?id=CRTK 
KaJOODYC). Princeton Landmarks in Mathematics. Princeton University Press. ISBN 0-691- 
00547-8; 1st pbk printing 
. Kuhn, Harold W. (1955). "Review of The Elements of Probability Theory and Some of its 
Applications by Harald Cramér". Physics Today. 8 (10): 22. Bibcode:1955PhT.....8;]..22C (https://ui. 
adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1955PhT.....8;..22C). doi:10.1063/1.3061792 (https://doi.org/10.1063%2F 
1.3061792). 
Heyde, Seneta 2001, p. 442.
